awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF Understanding the Effects of Incomplete Mixing on Mixing Corrosion: Pore-scale Visualization and Upscaling
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Michael A. Chen has been granted an NSF EAR Postdoctoral fellowship to study mixing induced calcite dissolution and develop outreach materials at the University of Minnesota – Twin Cities campus with Professor Peter K. Kang and Dr. Diana Dalbotten. Carbonate minerals, such as calcite, make up many natural rocks and soils, including many karst systems, and are also an important sink for carbon in the carbon cycle. Removal of these minerals by dissolution drives the evolution of subsurface landscapes and results in carbon release back into the carbon cycle, and vigorous dissolution can be spurred by even the simple mixing of waters saturated with different sources of calcite. This specific process, called mixing corrosion, is fundamentally a soil pore-scale process and known as a key mechanism for karst formation, but we still do not understand how this small-scale process can lead to the larger scale patterns of dissolution in time and space. Aquifer scale models used to study mixing corrosion typically assume that solutions are well mixed as soon as they encounter each other, however, this is not necessarily true at the smaller scale where incomplete mixing may leave solutions segregated, thus reducing the total calcite dissolution rate. Thus, the primary goal of this fellowship will be to experimentally study mixing corrosion of calcite at the microscale, and develop a framework for understanding how microscale flow, mixing, and chemical reaction affect calcite dissolution at larger scales. This framework and the fundamental knowledge gained through these studies can be extended to understand how other microscale processes influence larger scale processes, which can be used to improve predictions of landscape evolution, develop predictive models of carbon sequestration, and enhance efforts to remediate groundwater contaminants. This project will also support minority involvement in Earth Sciences through recruiting and mentoring of interns from underrepresented groups in the Earth Sciences, as well as through outreach with the Science Museum of Minnesota to improve public understanding of flow and chemistry of rocks and soils using new demonstration experiments.

There is a continuing need to better understand how the coupled processes of flow and geochemistry alter the dissolution or precipitation of calcite for its relevance in carbon cycling and the development of natural geologic formations, particularly karst. This is best exemplified in the process of mixing corrosion, where two solutions that are equilibrated with a mineral (i.e. calcite), but differing amounts of mineral constituents (i.e. CO2 and Ca), are mixed, resulting in an undersaturated solution that will dissolve calcite. While this process has been studied extensively with Darcy-scale models that assumes well-mixed conditions at pore scale, there are no reported observations of mixing corrosion at the pore scale, where incomplete mixing can strongly influence net dissolution by mixing corrosion. There is also increasing recognition that flow and transport at the field or aquifer scale is impacted by pore scale flow and reaction, thus there is need for a framework that can integrate pore-scale processes into the larger scale models. Key among these processes is how incomplete mixing of solutions drives variation in geochemical reaction rates and transport of dissolved minerals. Innovative microfluidic experiments and benchtop reactors using calcite minerals are used to study how parameters of flow and geochemical reaction influence mixing and subsequent dissolution of calcite. The experimental results will then be synthesized into a framework which is able to relate overall dissolution rate to the key parameters of flow, pore geometry, and geochemical conditions. This framework lays the groundwork to then understand how coupled flow and geochemistry at the pore scale influences geochemical reaction at larger scales, which will be broadly relevant to many environmental processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to further develop our understanding of the ways that groundwater flows interact with geochemistry. To do this, we sought to understand the shape of groundwater flows at very small scales, such as an individual crack in a rock, or a few pore spaces, would influence chemical reactions. To accomplish this, we proposed using computational simulations and microfluidic chips. Microfluidic chips are small laboratory tools that allow us to design and build flow channels which are similar to that we see in natural groundwaters, but are much easier to control and image compared to natural soils and rocks. While there are many different types of groundwater flows and associated chemical reactions, we wished to focus on higher speed flows, which can occur in karst, caves, and during industrial groundwater operations. The higher speed of these flows can create complex flow patterns very different from the ones seen at slow flow rates. We also wished to combine these complex flows, which we call weak inertial flows, with systems where different chemical reactions occur. We initially proposed studying a system where mixing of solutions drives dissolution of rocks, a process called mixing corrosion, which is thought to occur primarily with calcite or other carbonate rocks. The goal of this work was to understand how these reactions and flows influenced each other at small scales with the goal of building a conceptual model of the different regimes of flow and reaction which could be potentially observed in larger groundwater systems.

The outcomes of this project can be divided into two sections, results from the scientific investigations of the project, related to the above goal, and broader impacts, which are ways the fellowship helped the public in different ways. For scientific investigations, we produced research which showed that weak inertial flows are very important to a variety of groundwater geochemical processes. These flows enhance mixing of reactants, which can help enhance certain reactions, such as those used in groundwater remediation or mixing corrosion. We also showed that when considering a dissolving mineral, these flows dramatically alter where dissolution can occur, which is important for certain carbon sequestration methods as well as improving our understanding of rock weathering. We have presented these more detailed results of these projects at a few scientific conferences, and will be publishing a few academic papers on these projects in the coming years, which we hope to be open access. The fundamental understanding developed in these projects will be helpful in better understanding groundwater flow and chemistry.

 Beyond this scientific work, there were two additional major outcomes. First, this fellowship funded a student from a traditionally underrepresented background to work on some of the scientific projects as well as participate in an REU with other students. As a result of this student?s hard work, they were able to present the results of their summer research on these inertial flows at a few different conferences. The second major outcome is that this fellowship funded work with MN science teachers to help adapt their Earth Science curriculum to include studies of groundwater, which includes major concepts from physics and chemistry, and is immediately relevant to many MN communities. We developed a module on groundwater for high school science teachers as well as a cost-effective model groundwater system that can be used to demonstrate how water and chemicals (contaminants or nutrients) move in the ground. The results of this work were disseminated at a local teacher?s conference and we are continue work to further refine and disseminate these materials.
